column1: #Text=Derbyshire is a county in the English
#Text=– market town and home to the Bakewell Tart
#Text=The varied landscape of Derbyshire makes it an attractive destination for sightseers , particularly hikers .
#Text=The south is a low-level clayland area , dominated by the broad , flat , gravel-filled valley of the River Trent .
#Text=The north and central west of the county is classic limestone hills and valleys .

#Text=Further north , surrounding these limestone areas , are higher level moorlands , dotted with rock outcrops and gritstone edges , while the lower area are rolling hills and deep valleys with small picturesque villages that a hobbit might feel at home in .
#Text=The eastern part of the county consists of a rural and urban landscape influence by its industrial , mainly coal-mining , past .

#Text=Derbyshire also has many historical attractions from stately homes to early industrial heritage buildings , and includes the Derwent Valley Mills World Heritage Site - a long , wooded corridor running from Derby to Matlock and containing some of the first water-powered mills of the Industrial Revolution .
#Text=Derby people do have a noticeable accent but this is easily understood .
#Text=You may be greeted by Ey Up Mi Duck , do not be concerned it is not an insult but a friendly greeting .

#Text=To Derby and Chesterfield : Direct trains from many places including London ( St. Pancras station ) , Birmingham , Bristol , Oxford , Newcastle , York , Leeds , Sheffield , Edinburgh and Nottingham
#Text=To Buxton and Chapel-en-le-Frith : Trains from Manchester ( Piccadily station )
#Text=To Belper and Matlock : Trains from Derby and Nottingham
#Text=To Edale , Hope and Hathersage : Trains from Sheffield and Manchester
#Text=For train times , contact National Rail Enquiries , telephone 0845 748 4950 .
#Text=The nearest airports to Derbyshire are Manchester Airport and East Midlands Airport .
#Text=The M1 from London and Leeds runs along the eastern edge of Derbyshire while the A6 crosses from north west to south east of the county .
#Text=Coach services are operated by National Express to Derby from around the country .
#Text=Trent Barton connects the Derby to Chesterfield and Nottingham at very regular intervals on weekdays and weekends .
#Text=The ' Transpeak ' bus service by High Peak connects Derby with the Peak District and Manchester .
#Text=Local bus services operate between many of the towns in Derbyshire .
#Text=A number of villages are served by bus services , but many have only a limited frequency .
#Text=The buses are operated by numerous different companies , including Arriva , High Peak buses and Trent Barton .
#Text=The Derbyshire Wayfarer rover ticket is good value if travelling on more than one bus or train service .
#Text=It is valid on nearly all buses and trains within Derbyshire .
#Text=The Transpeak bus is the main service for crossing the county .
#Text=It runs from Nottingham via Derby , Belper , Matlock , Bakewell and Buxton to Manchester .
#Text=For timetable information see the Derbyshire County Council public transport website or phone Traveline on 0870 608 2608 .
#Text=Within the county , there are train services between Derby and Matlock and between Derby and Chesterfield .
#Text=Cheap Train Tickets to and from Derby .
#Text=runs services across Derbyshire plus high speed services to Derby from London , Leicester , Nottingham , Chesterfield and Sheffield .
#Text=The Peak District National Park - Britain 's first ever National Park , set up in 1951 .
#Text=A very large part of Derbyshire is within the Park ( though it also extends into parts of neighbouring counties ) .
#Text=Dovedale - a picturesque valley , very popular with visitors and so can be crowded on Summer weekends and Bank Holidays
#Text=High Peak Trail - path for cyclists and walkers along former railway line
#Text=Pennine Way - a long distance footpath , which starts in the north of the county
#Text=Sudbury Hall ( also includes The Museum of Childhood ) - south of Ashbourne near Uttoxeter
#Text=Crich Tramway Village ( also known as The National Tramway Museum )
#Text=There are many great country inns serving English pub food making exploring the villages very rewarding .
#Text=The tea rooms serve some excellent cakes .
#Text=Cream tea ( scones , clotted cream and jam ) makes a pleasant afternoon break , but also look out for locally made Bakewell pudding and Bakewell tarts .
#Text=Also do not miss checking out the local Fish & Chips takeaways , not just for fish and fries but also for the steak and kidney pies , chicken and mushroom , battered sausages and mushy peas .
#Text=The city of Derby also has some excellent Indian restaurants .
#Text=The county has a large number of pubs in the towns and in the country serving numerous brands of real ale .
